entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Taimodels recently released their rendition of QuÃ©bec City Jean Lesage International Airport (CYQB) for X-Plane 12. The airport serves the QuÃ©bec City metropolitan area and has a yearly average of 1.7 million passengers. It was established in 1939 as a military training facility for air observers, with the first flight only taking place two years later, on September 11, 1941. It was then known as RCAF Station LâAncienne-Lorette, and its wartime foundation laid the essential infrastructure (runways, hangars, and control tower) that would eventually be adapted for civil use. Its transition from military to civil use happened when World War 2 ended, with the Department of Transport taking over immediately. Early commercial flights connected QuÃ©bec to other major Canadian cities, fostering economic growth in the region. The 1950s and 1960s saw increased passenger numbers as air travel became more popular, requiring expansion work to accommodate the ever-growing number of people. Furthermore, the beginning of the jet age also demanded slightly longer jetways and aprons. In 2006, the administration invested over 65 million dollars in increasing the terminalâs passenger handling capacity and improving the overall quality of their services. The modernization included a terminal reconfiguration, the enlargement of waiting rooms, and the complete restructuring of the baggage handling area. The process was finished 2 years later, and the airport could now handle up to 1.4 million passengers. It was expanded again in 2011âat a cost of over 200 million dollarsâdoubling the terminalâs size. The project took 6 years to complete and also included a new runway, new taxiways, new deicing pads, and enhanced facilities. â Two years after the conclusion of the terminal expansion, further work was carried out to link the domestic and international terminals. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with high-quality models, custom ground markings, custom autogen around the airportâs area, performance-friendly optimization, and X-Plane 12âs weather textures. â Itâs available on SimMarket for roughly $20.49, requiring at least 931.19 MB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: PMDG Publishes Development Update for MSFS 2020/2024

PMDG recently published a new development update concerning their 777 lineup for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024 and provided a concrete release date for its upcoming 777LR.Â While PMDG was originally planning to push out a series of 777 updates a bit before FSExpo, they claim to have underestimated the amount of work required to prepare for it, ultimately deciding to hold off on pushing the updates until the dust was settled for good, in case something went wrong with the update. â They anticipate Microsoft will push out the 777 lineup update for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 sometime next week (777-300ER and 777F only), bringing it up to build 116. Itâs mostly a cleanup update, with no new features per se. The same timeframe applies to the update for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 users, which will become free for 2020 version owners. â Â The 777-200ER, on the other hand, is having issues with Microsoftâs intake process, and itâs unknown whether it will be available next week alongside the other family members.Â â Build 166 will also be available for PMDG.com customers on Tuesday, marking the first time since the airplanes were released that there is version parity between the marketplace and their own storefront.Â â The upcoming 777-200LR is undergoing its final testing phase and is scheduled to be released on July 15th. entry.title: efbX Releases New Video Preview Showcasing Upcoming Plugin Features
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. efbX has just released a new video preview on YouTube and Instagram, showcasing the user interface and upcoming features. Built by real pilots, efbX is an upcoming fully customizable, multi-platform Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) designed for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020, 2024, and Prepar3D. It aims to provide professional-grade features and seamless integration. At the heart of the efbX experience is the App Store, which enables users to access all their third-party flight simulation applications in one convenient location. Although most previews show efbX running on an iPad, the platform is designed as a web-based application, and will be able to run on virtually any device. efbX itself will be completely free to run; in addition, a selection of starter apps will be included; however, apps in the App Store may be paid. â efbX will feature integration with key services such as SimBrief, VATSIM and GSX, and will also support live weather updates. entry.title: Pepelatz Releases Yak-55M for XP12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Pepelatz Studio has recently released its debut aircraft for XP12, the Yakovlev Yak-55M, a Soviet-era, single-seat aerobatics plane, known for its extreme manoeuvrability. Developed in close collaboration with real-world Yak-55M pilots, the aircraft promises to deliver an authentic flight experience, designed for high-precision aerobatics. Created from scratch, the aircraft includes high-resolution PBR textures, photogrammetry-based geometry, and extensive cockpit detailing. Furthermore, the addon features accurate gauge behaviour and a vibration-simulated instrument panel. The addon gives the option to choose between Cold Start or Automatic Sequential Start, metric or imperial altimeters, and 8.33 or 25 kHz VHF radios. Flight dynamics were tuned with pilot input to reflect accurate behaviour across the entire flight envelope. The addon features a fully modelled M-14P engine, custom fuel, electrical, oil, and pneumatic systems, and includes a functional smoke system with weight impact. Failures and weather-dependent engine startup behaviour are also included. Included is an EFB interface that handles weight and balance, aircraft configuration, ground equipment, as well as an interactive walk-around.Â The addon comes with seven liveries, VR support an an FMOD sound suite with real-life recordings. The Pepelatz Yak-55M is available now on the X-Plane.org Store for $35.00. Stay updated with all the latest in flight simulation, right here on Threshold. entry.title: MK-Studios Announces Adelaide Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. MK-Studios has revealed Adelaide Airport as its next project for Microsoft Flight Simulator, with a release planned for next Friday. The scenery will support both MSFS 2020 and MSFS 2024, with a new, walkable jetway feature reserved for the newer simulator and its walkaround mode.Â Based on the announcement, the package will include a modelled terminal interior, and extensive detailing across the airport environment. Adelaide Airport is the primary airport serving Adelaide, in South Australia. Located roughly 6 kilometres west of the central business district, it is the countryâs fifth-busiest airport by passenger volume, with over 8.5 million travellers passing through in the 2024 financial year. Adelaide Airport accommodates domestic, international, and general aviation traffic, serving as a hub for Virgin Australia, a focus city for Qantas, and an operating base for Jetstar. The airport was first established in 1955, and operates over 250 flights daily to more than 30 destinations across Oceania, Asia, and North America. Adelaide is also equipped to handle large aircraft, including the Boeing 747 and Airbus A380. Additional details are expected in the days leading up to release. FSLabs has recently issued a new experimental update to their A321ceo and ceo for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, focusing on increasing stability, improving visual performance, and improving the handling, among other things. Update v11.0.1.309 aims to improve performance and lower VRAM usage, ensuring better headroom for users running very high resolutions or rocking cards with little VRAM to spare.
